body_html:
You can use a function to initialize a variable with a constant, the problem is that those constants become part of the graph and adding many of them could make it very big.

Instead the recommended way to initialize a variable with a value is using assign_from_values_fn:

init_assign_fn = assign_from_values_fn({'scope/weights': value})
sess.run(init_assign_fn)
body_text:
You can use a function to initialize a variable with a constant, the problem is that those constants become part of the graph and adding many of them could make it very big.
Instead the recommended way to initialize a variable with a value is using assign_from_values_fn:
init_assign_fn = assign_from_values_fn({'scope/weights': value})
sess.run(init_assign_fn)
body:
You can use a function to initialize a variable with a constant, the problem is that those constants become part of the graph and adding many of them could make it very big.

Instead the recommended way to initialize a variable with a value is using [assign_from_values_fn](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/contrib/framework/python/ops/variables.py#L447):

```
init_assign_fn = assign_from_values_fn({'scope/weights': value})
sess.run(init_assign_fn)
```
